description: soap +â€Ž box. The figurative use of the word derives from the fact that soap products in the US used to be commonly transported to stores in large wooden boxes. It used to be common for individuals to give impromptu rally speeches to their neighbors by finding something to stand on like a soapbox.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Any physical or media platform which gives prominence to the person on it and the views they espouse.
examples: The madman obtained a soapbox which he stood on at the corner of Broadway and Wall street, to shout out his prophesy of the end of the world.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A talk about one's pet topic (or the topic itself), especially when only tangentially relevant to an ongoing discussion.
examples: He's been on his soapbox all day about the new football coach.

verbs.description: soapbox (third-person singular simple present soapboxes, present participle soapboxing, simple past and past participle soapboxed)

entries.meaning: To give a speech from (or as if from) a soapbox.
